data.title: 33 Best Inspirational Songs to Give You an Uplifting Boost
data.meta_description: In need of a little musical motivation? Look no further than our list of the 33 best inspirational songs of all time.
data.text:
Music is a great motivator. Whether you need a push to finally finish that novel or apply for that dream job or just get out of bed in the morning, the right song can get you there. In some cases, it can be any song that means something to you. But the best inspirational songs don‚Äôt just nudge you toward your goal - they make you feel like the person singing is pursuing the same mission right alongside you.

Sure, rock stars aren‚Äôt always folks who may have quite the same problems as the rest of us, but unless their dad is George Harrison many of them have struggled at some point in their lives - or at the very least needed some inspiration of their own. On this list of the 33 best inspirational songs of all-time, you‚Äôll find everything from aspirational rap classics to rock‚Äôn‚Äôroll affirmations to pop stars who inspire simply by existing. No matter what you need to get done, these jams will help get you there.

RECOMMENDED:

üí™ The best motivational songs

‚ö°Ô∏è The best songs about power

üí∏ The best songs about money

‚úä The best protest songs

üèã The best workout songs

1. ‚ÄòAin‚Äôt No Mountain High Enough‚Äô by Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrell

Originally recorded by Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrell in 1967, this Ashford and Simpson-penned song was covered by Diana Ross three years later, becoming a hit. The original, however, is still the most uplifting version, full of hope and determination, proving that love can conquer anything that stands in its way. If at all possible, seek out the live version to take the motivational factor up to stratospheric heights.

2. ‚ÄòI Will Survive‚Äô by Gloria Gaynor

Another number that proves life goes on after a break-up, this ultimately empowering disco anthem is a classic motivational tune and an essential track on any Pride playlist. Gaynor later used it as the backdrop for a 2013 anthology of inspirational stories called We Will Survive. Destiny‚Äôs Child may have shouted about it the loudest, but GG was the original survivor.

Advertising

3. ‚ÄòLose Yourself‚Äô by Eminem

Putting all the memes about ‚ÄòMom‚Äôs spaghetti‚Äô aside, if you‚Äôve ever felt like the underdog (and who hasn‚Äôt at some point?), then ‚ÄòLose Yourself‚Äô is for you. Em's Oscar-winning pick-up anthem is all about seizing the moment and giving it all you‚Äôve got, plus a bit more ‚Äì and what‚Äôs more inspirational than that?

4. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm Still Standing‚Äô by Elton John

Originally written as a kiss-off after a breakup, this seriously up-tempo Elton John smash has been co-opted by the masses as an anthem of steely resiliance for basically any occasion. It‚Äôs a musical embodiment of perseverence from a man who has been defying the odds for decades.

Advertising

5. ‚ÄòSurvivor‚Äô by Destiny‚Äôs Child

A true lesson in resilience from Queen Bey and co, this classic is a motivational poster turned into an R&B banger. The song came off the back of problems within the group, but it silenced their critics and inspired fans in the process.

6. ‚ÄòHarder, Better, Faster, Stronger‚Äô by Daft Punk

Even the title of this dance duo‚Äôs repetitive electro-banger is seriously motivational. It‚Äôs been hijacked a bit by gym bros, but don‚Äôt let that stop it from picking you up when you need a lift. For extra motivational kudos, the track was later sampled by Kanye on his 2007 hit ‚ÄòStronger‚Äô.

Advertising

7. ‚Äò(Your Love Keeps Lifting Me) Higher and Higher‚Äô by Jackie Wilson

Possibly the greatest feelgood song of all time, this tune is three minutes of pure happiness and will fling you straight into summer. There are loads of cover versions knocking around, but ‚Äì surprise surprise ‚Äì the joyous original still wins hands down.

8. ‚Äò***Flawless‚Äô by Beyonc√©

Sampling Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie‚Äôs inspirational feminist call to arms, there are many layers to ‚Äò***Flawless‚Äô and just too many motivational lines to count. The overriding message, however, rings clear and true: ladies, you‚Äôre flawless ‚Äì and you shouldn‚Äôt be defined by a relationship.

Advertising

9. ‚ÄòBorn to Run‚Äô by Bruce Springsteen

The Boss‚Äôs defining 1975 album Born to Run was the one that catapulted him to stardom, and its title track remains inspirational, also acting as the highlight of every epic Bruce live show. Written as a love letter to a girl named Wendy, it‚Äôs all about running away ‚Äì which initially doesn‚Äôt sound too inspirational, until you realise it‚Äôs also about starting all over again with a fresh outlook. Plus it has a killer sax solo courtesy of the late, great Clarence Clemons.

10. ‚ÄòJuicy‚Äô by the Notorious BIG

Hip-hop is full of come-up anthems, but this is the greatest of them all. The late Christopher Wallace usually put his unparalleled storytelling acumen to use painting cinematic images of crimes he may or may not have actually committed, but on his signature anthem, he keeps the language simple yet vivid, describing how he went from high school dropout to ‚Äòputtin' five karats in my baby girl's ear‚Äô with such detail it almost feels like it could be your story. But of course, it‚Äôs not - it‚Äôs one of the singular tales in all American culture, even if it ultimately ended in tragedy.

Advertising

11. ‚ÄòHeroes‚Äô by David Bowie

From the second album in his ‚ÄòBerlin Trilogy‚Äô, this is one of Bowie‚Äôs signature songs. Over the years, it‚Äôs become associated with optimism and hope ‚Äì some even associate it with playing a part in the fall of the Berlin Wall, after Bowie performed it live in front of the Reichstag in 1987, in an emotionally charged concert. It's since become a staple of movie trailers, which isn't quite as stirring as scoring the crumbling of a monument to oppression, but is impactful nonetheless.

12. ‚ÄòMove On Up‚Äô by Curtis Mayfield

This has to be what plays on the elevator up to heaven. With its perpetually ascending swirl of percussion, guitar and triumphant horn blasts, this soul classic classic unfurls over nine euphoric minutes, propelled forward Mayfield‚Äôs sweet falsetto insisting you keep moving and keep your on the prize, no matter what complications may befall your path. Kanye West, of course, cut the tempo in half for ‚ÄòTouch the Sky,‚Äô which is inspirational in its own right.

Advertising

13. 'Roar‚Äô by Katy Perry

A perfect companion to the razzle-dazzle of ‚ÄòFirework,‚Äô ‚ÄòRoar‚Äô is very much a feminist anthem, and one of modern pop‚Äôs best. But it‚Äôs also a hair-raising tribute rising above bullying to fully realize yourself, then shouting it from the mountaintops. Or, in Katy Perry‚Äôs case, from the shoulders of a gigantic kaiju-like robotic lion in the middle of a stadium.

14. ‚ÄòStarted from the Bottom‚Äô by Drake

Once upon a time, before he was a certified loverboy, Drake was just like you, arguing with his mum and sitting in traffic. Now he wears all the chains ‚Äì even when he‚Äôs doing the washing up ‚Äì to remind him how far he‚Äôs come. After listening to this for a few minutes, you'll feel like you and your crew can go that far too.

Advertising

15. ‚ÄòGirl on Fire‚Äô by Alicia Keys

Seemingly penned as a walk-on song for Hunger Games tribute Katniss Everdeen, Keys ‚Äì the human embodiment of grace and confidence ‚Äì penned this rousing anthem about the ability to stand up to any and all challenges, her voice practically soaring above her signature piano work. The message? Keep your head in the clouds, continue dreaming‚Ä¶ and burn any and all naysayers to the ground.

16. ‚ÄòI Won‚Äôt Back Down‚Äô by Tom Petty

The late Wilbury‚Äôs ode to picking yourself up from the mud is one of the rocker‚Äôs biggest hits thanks to its universal message of staring adversity in the face and standing your ground. It‚Äôs a common theme, but with Petty‚Äôs ascendant bridge paired with one his catchiest melodies, it‚Äôs become the stuff of underdog legend.

Advertising

17. ‚ÄòTitanium‚Äô by David Guetta ft. SIA

‚ÄòYou shoot me down, but I won‚Äôt fall/I am titanium‚Äô SIA wails from behind a wall of hair on David Guetta‚Äôs breakout anthem to confidence, and it‚Äôs almost impossible to not feel like you could stop a train with your bare hands while listening to the beat climb to the sky.

18. ‚ÄòTrue Colors‚Äô by Cyndi Lauper

This simple, stripped-down ode to being your best authentic self has been striking a chord with outsiders for over three decades. It's been particularly embraced by the LGBT+ community, one Lauper has supported for years, so it's heartening to know that she co-founded the True Colors Fund in 2008 to help fight homelessness among queer young people.

Advertising

19. ‚ÄòTouch the Sky‚Äô by Kanye West

The rapper has a few inspirational songs under his belt, but ‚ÄòTouch the Sky‚Äô ‚Äì with its Evel Kneivel-inspired video and aspirational lyrics ‚Äì is up there as being one of the most uplifting, motivational tunes of all time, sung by someone who knows a thing or two about self-motivation.

20. ‚ÄòThe Show Must Go on‚Äô by Queen

While ‚ÄòWe Are the Champions‚Äô is the conventional choice here, the final track from Queen‚Äôs 1991 album ‚ÄòInnuendo‚Äô was recorded when Freddie Mercury was gravely ill, from complications due to HIV/AIDS. Guitarist Brian May reportedly had concerns about whether Mercury would be able to sing the song, who responded with ‚ÄòI‚Äôll fucking do it darling‚Äô, before downing a shot of vodka and delivering a stellar performance. Nailed like a true icon.

Advertising

21. ‚ÄòUnwritten‚Äô by Natasha Bedingfield

This uplifting smash hit from 2004 encourages us to admit that we make mixtakes, learn from them and then ‚ÄòLive your life with arms wide open‚Äô. Every line of this tune ‚Äìwhich earned Bedingfield a Grammy nomination and helped her break the US ‚Äì oozes encouragment and champions the possibilities of a fresh start.

22. ‚ÄòStronger (What Doesn‚Äôt Kill You)‚Äô by Kelly Clarkson

‚ÄòWhat doesn‚Äôt kill you makes you stronger,‚Äô sings the first ever winner of American Idol on this 2012 hit, which takes lyrical inspiration, believe it or not, from Friedrich Nietzsche. This one is all about dusting yourself off and getting the hell back out there, no matter what.

Advertising

23. ‚ÄòEncore‚Äô by Jay Z

An unapologetic list of the rapper‚Äôs attributes and achievements, ‚ÄòEncore‚Äô was called one of his ‚Äòhappiest cuts‚Äô by one critic. Crucially, it‚Äôs also a warning to other rappers that might follow in his path: Jay Z is the greatest, and he knows it. Sometimes, all you need to be inspired is your bad self. Many fans cite the Linkin Park remix with the late Chester Bennington as the superior cut, but the Black Album version ‚Äì with John Legend, Kanye and GLC providing support ‚Äì is the definitive version.

24. ‚ÄòLive Forever‚Äô by Oasis

This 1994 hit was a response to Nirvana‚Äôs ‚ÄòI Hate Myself and Want to Die‚Äô (the B-side to ‚ÄòPennyroyal Tea‚Äô, intended as a jokey response to Kurt being asked how he was), with Noel Gallagher saying he wasn‚Äôt ‚Äòhaving that‚Ä¶ kids don‚Äôt need to be hearing that nonsense.‚Äô The result? A brazenly optimistic indie anthem full of arrogant Mancunian swagger.

Advertising

25. ‚ÄòI‚Äôm the Best‚Äô by Nicki Minaj

‚ÄòI hear they comin‚Äô for me / because the top is lonely,‚Äô Minaj sings on the standout track from her first album, Pink Friday. Looking back now, it‚Äôs obvious at this point that Minaj knew she was about to become the globe-smashing star she is today ‚Äì and it‚Äôs this level of self-belief that we all should aspire to have... unless that self-belief concerns medical advice, in which case, maybe listen to doctors instead.

26. ‚ÄòUnstoppable‚Äô by Santigold

This Diplo-produced track became massively popular after it soundtracked a viral video back in 2009: one guy dancing enthusiastically on his own at Sasquatch! Festival, as Santigold plays a live version of the song. This one dude gradually inspires hundreds of others to rush towards him and join in the fun, inadvertently starting a huge dance party. Great, uplifting vibes, pure and simple.

Advertising

27. ‚ÄòSo What?‚Äô by Pink

Pink's a fount for inspirational tunes, but her ‚Äòscrew you‚Äô to her husband (they had separated at the time) was praised by critics for its empowering message. It‚Äôs not hard to see why. The song is full of aggressive swagger and is definitely one to scream along to if you‚Äôve had a bad day: ‚ÄòI got a brand new attitude and I‚Äôm gonna wear it tonight / I wanna get in trouble, I wanna start a fight.‚Äô A pretty clear statement of intent.

28. ‚ÄòCan‚Äôt Hold Us Down (ft ‚ÄòLil Kim)‚Äô by Christina Aguilera

Ladies, if you‚Äôre sick and tired of gendered double standards, you‚Äôve got two allies in Xtina and Lil‚Äò Kim. This song is a mega-bold statement on female sexuality, with a brilliant accompanying video that features creepy men getting their comeuppance. It's the polar opposite of Christina‚Äôs other motivational hall-of-famer ‚ÄòBeautiful,‚Äô and all the better for it.

Advertising

29. ‚ÄòThe Harder They Come‚Äô by Jimmy Cliff

Owner of one of Jamaica‚Äôs sweetest voices, Cliff burst through internationally playing a troubled young singer in the 1972 film The Harder They Come, whose soundtrack brought reggae to the wider world and contained one of the genre‚Äôs most potent anthems of defiance. Despite his honeyed delivery, you know Cliff means it when he sings, ‚ÄòI‚Äôd rather be a free man in my grave/Than living as a puppet or a slave.‚Äô

30. ‚ÄòDon't Give Up‚Äô by Peter Gabriel and Kate Bush

Elton John famously said that this song is the one that ‚Äòsaved his life‚Äô and helped him get sober. Though Peter Gabriel‚Äôs verses are those of despair, Kate Bush swoops in to provide an optimistic counterpoint with words of hope and encouragement: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt give up / you‚Äôre not beaten yet‚Äô.

Advertising

31. ‚ÄòEye of the Tiger‚Äô by Survivor

Yet more survivors, this time providing the tune that got Rocky Balboa out of his rut and back in the ring (after a brief sunrise beach run with Apollo Creed, naturally). We defy you to hear those thudding, opening guitar chords and not feel 110 percent ready to deal with whatever nonsense the day throws at you. Just like Rocky, you got this ‚Äì just don‚Äôt start punching people, okay?

32. ‚ÄòBreak My Stride‚Äô by Matthew Wilder

Wilder‚Äôs synth-pop/reggae hit saw new life in the ‚Äò90s when Puff Daddy sampled it on ‚ÄòCan‚Äôt Nobody Hold Me Down,‚Äô a song that serves the dual function as a self-motivating banger and a tribute to Puff Daddy‚Äôs favorite subject, Puff Daddy. But the stripped-down 1983 original is a simple earworm about the urge to continue moving forward no matter the obstacle, and as such it‚Äôs endured much further than any song featuring rapper-turned-preacher Mase could ever hope.

Advertising

33. ‚ÄòExpress Yourself‚Äô by Madonna

One of Madonna's very best pop songs is also a feminist classic. Empowerment has always been a core theme in La Ciccone's work, and it comes to the fore in this funk-fuelled floor-filler written as an homage to Sly & The Family Stone. ‚ÄòWhat you need is a big strong hand to lift you to your higher ground,‚Äô she tells her female listeners, urging them to find a partner who treats them right. Preach, sis, preach.
